metadata.title: California Water Infrastructure Funding Programs
metadata.description: Machine-readable catalog of federal, state, and private funding programs for water infrastructure projects
metadata.disclaimer: Eligibility information is for guidance only. Always verify current requirements directly with the administering agency before applying.

programs.name: Drinking Water State Revolving Fund
programs.description: Provides affordable financing for drinking water infrastructure projects throughout California, including treatment, distribution, storage, consolidation, and source development.

fundingRange.notes: FY 2025-26 loan capacity $300M base program; ~$1B in grant/principal forgiveness available

interestRate.notes: 50% of state GO Bond rate; 0% for small SDAC systems

additionalCriteria: Authorized Representative Resolution from governing body

principalForgiveness.conditions: Available for small DAC/SDAC communities (population ≤10,000, MHI <80% statewide); up to 100% of eligible project cost

programs.ragQuery: What are the DWSRF eligibility requirements, interest rates, and principal forgiveness options for drinking water projects?

programs.name: Clean Water State Revolving Fund
programs.description: Federal-state partnership providing low-interest financing for water quality projects including wastewater treatment, stormwater management, water recycling, and nonpoint source pollution control.

fundingRange.notes: No maximum per project; FY 2025-26 total fundable list ~$2.8B; ~$514M in principal forgiveness

interestRate.notes: 50% of most recent GO Bond rate (Nov 2025); historical range 0.80%-3.00%

additionalCriteria: Priority scoring system (max 20 points; FY 2025-26 cutoff: 13 points)

principalForgiveness.conditions: BIL General Supplemental: 49% as principal forgiveness; Emerging Contaminants: 100% principal forgiveness

programs.ragQuery: What are the CWSRF program details for wastewater, stormwater, and water recycling project financing?

programs.name: Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience
programs.description: Comprehensive program ensuring all Californians have access to safe and affordable drinking water through emergency response, technical assistance, consolidation support, and long-term infrastructure development.

interestRate.notes: Grant program — no repayment required for most DAC/SDAC projects

additionalCriteria: Priority given to systems on Failing or At-Risk list

programs.ragQuery: What does the SAFER program cover and who is eligible for safe drinking water grants and emergency funding?

programs.name: Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act
programs.description: Federal credit assistance for large water infrastructure projects too large or complex for traditional state revolving fund programs, providing long-term, low-cost supplemental financing.

fundingRange.notes: $20M minimum for large communities; $5M minimum for small communities (≤25,000); max 49% of eligible project costs

interestRate.notes: Equal to or exceeding U.S. Treasury rate for similar maturity; locked at closing

additionalCriteria: 15% of funds set aside for small community projects

programs.ragQuery: What are the WIFIA loan program requirements for large water infrastructure projects?

programs.name: USDA Water and Waste Disposal Loan and Grant Program
programs.description: Primary federal financing mechanism for rural water and sanitation projects, providing long-term low-interest loans combined with grants to communities that cannot obtain adequate credit through conventional channels.

fundingRange.notes: No stated cap — based on need and fund availability

additionalCriteria: Rural areas and towns with 10,000 or fewer residents
Must demonstrate inability to obtain credit elsewhere

programs.ragQuery: What USDA rural water programs are available for small communities and what are the eligibility requirements?
